sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
In this contribution to the American Field and Short-tail crickets, two new species from the continental and insular area of Colombia are described. Anurogryllus ( Urogryllus ) edithsantosum n. sp. from the Meta department , is more related to some Caribbean species, and its genital structure fits the morphological current definition of the subgenus Urogryllus , although it has pseudepiphallic median lophi covered with hairs, as it happens in the species of the subgenus Pilosogryllus . The same way, Gryllus ( Gryllus ) providiensis n. sp. from Providencia Island, San Andres Archipelago is described, this new species has thick hairs on the pronotum as Gryllus ( Gryllus ) assimilis (widely distributed in America), as well as the color pattern of the cephalic capsule; but the new species is smaller in size, and has a particular organization in the harp veins of the tegmina, which only resembles Gryllus ( Gryllus ) marchena from the Galapagos Archipelago ( Ecuador ), from which it differs markedly in its morphology. Finally, the status of the Gryllus species
, distributed in Latin America and the Caribbean, is reviewed, and it is recorded which species have acoustic records, and from here we start with the review of this peculiar genus in Latin America.
Key words: Cricket diversity, Latin America, Caribbean, genital morphology

sec.title: Resumen
sec.p: En esta contribución a los grillos de campo americanos se describe dos nuevas especies del área continental e insular de Colombia . Anurogryllus ( Urogryllus ) edithsantosum n. sp. proveniente del departamento del Meta , y que está más relacionada con algunas especies caribeñas, y en su estructura genital encaja a la definición morfológica del subgénero Urogryllus , aunque presenta el lóbulo medio del pseudepifalo cubierto de pelos, tal como sucede en las especies del subgénero Pilosogryllus . De igual modo, se describe a Gryllus ( Gryllus ) providiensis n. sp. de la Isla de Providencia, Archipiélago de San Andrés, esta nueva especie presenta pelos gruesos en el pronoto como en Gryllus ( Gryllus ) assimilis (ampliamente distribuida en América), al igual que el patrón de coloración de la capsula cefálica; pero la nueva especie es de menor tamaño, y tiene una organización particular en las venas del harpa de la tegmina, que solo se asemeja a Gryllus ( Gryllus ) marchena del Archipiélago de Galápagos ( Ecuador ), de la cual difiere notoriamente en su morfología. Finalmente, se revisa el estatus de las especies del género Gryllus , distribuidas en Latinoamérica y el Caribe, y se registra que especies tienen registros acústicos y de aquí partir en la revisión de este peculiar género en Latinoamérica.
Palabras clave: Diversidad de grillos, Latinoamérica, Caribe, morfología genital

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The present contribution records and describes new species of the genera Anurogryllus Saussure, 1877
and Gryllus from Colombia . This paper is the continuation to the study of the Colombian Gryllidea and another adjacent regions, with previous contributions to Gryllidae ( Cadena-Castañeda, 2011a , Cadena-Castañeda & Noriega, 2015 ; Cadena-Castañeda & Tíjaro, 2020 ; Cadena-Castañeda & García García, 2020 ; Desutter et al ., 2014),
Phalangopsidae ( Cadena-Castañeda & García García, 2012 )
and Gryllotalpidae ( Cadena-Castañeda 2011b , 2015a , b). More contributions to Grylloidea and Gryllotalpoidea are coming forward for future publications.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: Specimen preparation. The studied specimens were deposited at the Museo de Historia Natural de la Universidad Distrital Francisco José de Caldas , Colección de Entomología y Aracnología ( CAUD ). Lateral and dorsal view photographs were taken with a Nikon D3400 digital camera, and the remaining morphological characters with a Carl Zeiss Stemi 2000–C stereomicroscope.

The dissection of genitalia was made based on Cadena-Castañeda’s work (2015a). Male genitalia follow Desutter (1987) , modified in Desutter-Grandcolas (2003) : arc , ectophallic arc ec.f ., ectophallic fold, en.c ., endophallic cavity, l.l ., pseudepiphallic lateral lophi, m.l ., pseudepiphallic median lophi, ps.a ., pseudepiphallic apodeme, ps.p ., pseudepiphallic paramere, r. , rami, d. cav. , dorsal cavity. The wing venation nomenclature we follow Desutter-Grancolas et al . (2017).

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Comments. This genus is distributed from the United States to Argentina , including the Greater and Lesser Antilles. Contains 37 species in four recently established subgenera (
Cigliano et al ., 2021
). They are known by the common name of “Short-tailed cricket” because at least in the subgenus Anurogryllus , the ovipositor of females is very short and slightly exceeds the length of the subgenital plate ( Walker, 1973 ), females of the other subgenera have a welldeveloped ovipositor, sometimes exceeding the length of the hind femur ( Randell, 1964 ; Gorochov, 2019 ), discarding the ovipositor length as a generic character, as was the case in the past, and rather, it is the structure of the male genitalia which defines the genus ( Randell, 1964 ; García-Novo, 2002). Anurogryllus is very diverse since the range of its distribution has several gaps where in the future many species may be found since the distribution of its species is restricted (except Anurogryllus ( Anurogryllus ) muticus (De Geer, 1773))
and several examples are sympatric.
http://lsid.speciesfile.org/urn:lsid: Orthoptera .speciesfile.org:TaxonName:514177

Etymology. Dedicated to the memory of the social leader Edith del Consuelo Santos Jiménez, murdered in 2014, in the Chichimene village, Acacias, Meta , for her defense of the environment and the people of the oil sector.

Type material.Holotype .
Male. Colombia , Meta , Acacias , Vrd. La Esmeralda , Finca La Bonita. 3.972 260, -73.726315. 514 m . 21 April 2004 . J. Molano ( CAUD )
. Paratype . Male, same data as holotype.
Female. Unknown.
Measurements (mm): LB: 11–12. Pr: 4–4.5. Teg.: 6–6.5. HF: 14. HT: 10.

Comparison. This new species is more similar to Caribbean species such as A. ( U .) amolgosOtte & Perez-Gelabert, 2009 , A. ( U .) gnomusOtte & Perez-Gelabert, 2009 and A. ( U .) niguaOtte & Perez-Gelabert, 2009 , than the continental species of the subgenus Urogryllus . It is distinguished from A. ( U .) amolgos because the tegmina reach the base of the second abdominal tergite and the apex of the median lophi is lanceolate and without undulations on the lateral edges of the new species, in contrast, A. ( U .) amolgos the tegmina cover slightly more than half of the abdomen and the apex of the median lophi is narrow and wavy. A. ( U .) edithsantosum n. sp. differs in the incision of the median lophi, which is deeper and wider to A. ( U .) gnomus . The new species has the ectophallic fold of medium size, but in A . ( U .) nigua is elongated, in lateral view the median lophi and lateral lophi of pseudepiphallus looks altogether like a snout, and between these the ectophallic fold emerges like a tongue. A. ( U .) edithsantosum n. sp. differs from the three mentioned species, in its larger size, brown color of the head, and the pseudepiphallic median lophi is covered with hairs (as the species of the subgenus Pilosogryllus ), in contrast, the other species are of medium to small size, the head is black, and the pseudepiphallic median lophi is hairless.
http://lsid.speciesfile.org/urn:lsid: Orthoptera .speciesfile.org:TaxonName:514178
Etymology. It refers to the Providencia Island, Archipelago of San Andres , from where this species was collected.

Type material.Holotype .
Male. Colombia , Providencia Island , road to “Pico” 13.346 994, -81.374616. 300 m . J. Arias ( CAUD )
. Paratypes .
Female adult, two females and one male subadults with same data as holotype
.
Measurements (mm) male/female: LB: 17/20. Pr: 3.5/4. Teg.: 12/14. HF: 8/9. HT: 7.5/8.

Comparison. This new species is similar to G . ( G .) assimilis in its habitus, conspicuous bristles in the pronotum, epicranial suture and pale circumocular area, although the new species is smaller than G . ( G. ) assimilis , and the venation of the tegmina is different ( G . ( G. ) assimilis have 4–5 harp veins). Although the coloration of the Gryllus species
is variable, some patterns remain, and the new species has yellow legs and wings (especially the tegmina with a light-yellow spot at the base), in contrast, G . ( G. ) assimilis has darker coloring patterns, usually with legs and tegmina in shades of brown.

Few Gryllus species
have less than 4 harp veins, in the Caribbean species, it happens in G . ( G. ) arijuaOtte & Perez-Gelabert, 2009 and G . ( G. ) providiensis n. sp. in both there are 3 veins, but in G . ( G. ) arijua all originate from the stridulation vein (Cu2 traditionally, CuPb vein sensu Desutter-Grandcolas et al ., (2017)), but in the new species, only the second and third veins of the harp are born from the stridulating crest, the first vein arises from the second vein and in turn branches into a thin and short vein that is not considered an additional vein of the harp, this is peculiar to G . ( G. ) providiensis n. sp. , as the well-documented Caribbean and Neotropical species do not have this condition. The new species also differs from G . ( G .) arijua , in its coloration and length of the tegmina, which reaches the seventh abdominal segment, in contrast, G . ( G. ) arijua , has darker tones, resembling more to G . ( G .) assimilis , brown hind femur, with dark brown stripes and the tegmina covers until the last abdominal segment.

Comments. Recent publications have suggested using acoustic data to complement the description of new taxa for Gryllus , since they do not present significant variability that allows defining species with genitalia, as is traditionally done with crickets ( Weissman & Gray, 2019 ). But the description of G . ( G .) providiensis n. sp. , maybe an exception, due to its particular morphology, differing conspicuously from the closest species, as mentioned in the comparison. Also, the organization of the harp veins is not shared with the other Caribbean and continental species. Only G . ( G. ) marchenaOtte & Peck, 1997 from the Galapagos Archipelago has a similar pattern, but this species differs from G . ( G .) providiensis n. sp. since all the Galapagean species have short wings and a more elongated ovipositor, and a completely black cephalic head.

( G .) assimilis in its habitus, conspicuous bristles in the pronotum, epicranial suture and pale circumocular area, although the new species is smaller than G . ( G. ) assimilis , and the venation of the tegmina is different ( G . ( G. ) assimilis have 4–5 harp veins). Although the coloration of the Gryllus species
is variable, some patterns remain, and the new species has yellow legs and wings (especially the tegmina with a light-yellow spot at the base), in contrast, G . ( G. ) assimilis has darker coloring patterns, usually with legs and tegmina in shades of brown.

Few Gryllus species
have less than 4 harp veins, in the Caribbean species, it happens in G . ( G. ) arijuaOtte & Perez-Gelabert, 2009 and G . ( G. ) providiensis n. sp. in both there are 3 veins, but in G . ( G. ) arijua all originate from the stridulation vein (Cu2 traditionally, CuPb vein sensu Desutter-Grandcolas et al ., (2017)), but in the new species, only the second and third veins of the harp are born from the stridulating crest, the first vein arises from the second vein and in turn branches into a thin and short vein that is not considered an additional vein of the harp, this is peculiar to G . ( G. ) providiensis n. sp. , as the well-documented Caribbean and Neotropical species do not have this condition. The new species also differs from G . ( G .) arijua , in its coloration and length of the tegmina, which reaches the seventh abdominal segment, in contrast, G . ( G. ) arijua , has darker tones, resembling more to G . ( G .) assimilis , brown hind femur, with dark brown stripes and the tegmina covers until the last abdominal segment.

Comments. Recent publications have suggested using acoustic data to complement the description of new taxa for Gryllus , since they do not present significant variability that allows defining species with genitalia, as is traditionally done with crickets ( Weissman & Gray, 2019 ). But the description of G . ( G .) providiensis n. sp. , maybe an exception, due to its particular morphology, differing conspicuously from the closest species, as mentioned in the comparison. Also, the organization of the harp veins is not shared with the other Caribbean and continental species. Only G . ( G. ) marchenaOtte & Peck, 1997 from the Galapagos Archipelago has a similar pattern, but this species differs from G . ( G .) providiensis n. sp. since all the Galapagean species have short wings and a more elongated ovipositor, and a completely black cephalic head.

sec.title: About the status of Gryllus species
sec.p:
For the species, Gryllus ( Gryllus ) chichimecus Saussure, 1897
, G. ( G. ) miopteryx Saussure, 1877
, G. ( G .) bicolor Saussure, 1874
and G. ( G .) assimilispallida Saussure, 1897, their type specimens are lost, and they have not been found in any European collection where Henri de Saussure usually studied and deposited his specimens. In addition, the localities are imprecise, the descriptions are very brief. Taking into account the uniformity of the generic morphology, it makes it impossible to identify these species with the available information. G. ( G .) assimilispallida is considered a variety of G . assimilis in its original description, but currently, specimens with locality data are labeled with specimens identified as G. aztecus Saussure, 1859
(current synonym of G. assimilis ), questioning the validity of G. ( G .) assimilispallida . G. ( G .) bicolor from Guyana , with the missing type specimen, a male with a locality of Peru is referenced as this species, but it is not considered a type specimen, so the identity of this species cannot be certified. With the current status of these species, we would consider them as nomina dubia . Recent communication with Dr. David Weissman indicates he is preparing a manuscript in which he will designate neotypes for them. For this reason, we abstain from proposing these species as nomina dubia and we look forward to the future contribution by Dr. Weissman.

The status of four other species should be reviewed, even though the type specimens exist, but are in poor condition, the localities are imprecise, and the types are females (practically impossible to reliably identify) and no relevant data has been provided since their original description, do not allow a good identification: 1)G. ( G. ) mundusWalker, 1869 described with locality Brazil and proposed by
Weissman et al . (1980)
as a synonym of G. assimilis , but recently revalidated (
Weissman et al . 2009
). This species was described based on a female, and due to its imprecise distribution in one of the most biodiverse regions of the planet, it makes it difficult to identify multiple species that may inhabit Brazil . 2)G. ( G. ) signatusWalker, 1869 described with locality “ Venezuela ”, was described based on non-conspecific female and male, the brief description focused on the characters of the female ( Walker, 1869 ), with the latter the name-bearing specimen. No additional data has been provided since its description permits identification. 3)G. ( G. ) contingensWalker, 1869 described based on two females , one from St. Vincent and the other from Jamaica , synonymized under G. parilisWalker, 1869 by Chopard (1967) and revalidated by
Weissman et al . (2009)
. This species is not recorded for Brazil as mentioned by
Weissman et al . (2009)
, perhaps it was confusion when revalidating the species, including the distribution of G. parilis . 4)G. ( G. ) scudderianus Saussure, 1874
with locality “l’Amerique Septeptrionale” =North America, which currently includes Part of Mexico, the United States and Canada , a very wide area with numerous Gryllus species.
On the other hand, this species was described based on a female and a male in MNHN (Paris), but currently, only one female has been found that may be the probable syntype .

There are still Gryllus species
that were originally described only with females and accompanied by immature males in their type series. Examples such as G. ( G. ) bermudensis Caudell, 1903
or G. ( G. ) galapageius Scudder, 1893
, which we consider as valid because in subsequent contributions its status was clarified, including males from typical localities, complementing the morphological information with acoustic data and distribution ranges ( Leroy, 1966 ; Kevan, 1980 ; Otte & Peck, 1997 ; Otte & Perez-Gelabert, 2009 ), thus making it possible to carry out a good identification of the species, and keeping the names of both taxa stable. The Gryllus species
described based on males, from Central and South America that still prevail are those whose acoustic repertoire is mostly unknown. These species can be studied in the future with the identification of specimens from the type localities that agree with the morphological characteristics of the types and subsequently obtain their songs.

Here we begin with the taxonomy of this recognized genus of crickets for Latin America, we hope to be able to cover and contribute as Weissman et al ., (1980) and Weissman & Gray (2019) , clarify the status of the still valid species and complete the biological data for this purpose, in addition to describing new taxa. Although it is worth noting that colleagues have given important previous contributions for species from Meso and South America: Leroy (1966) , described songs and interactions for various Gryllus species
and other species of crickets. Otte & Peck (1997) described 7 species with the most songs, all species from the Galapagos. Desutter (1990) in her doctoral thesis includes an annex with a preliminary study of the genus, grouping species and morphospecies, with morphometric characters.
David et al . (2003)
compare the songs emitted by three morphospecies from Brazil , also includes the morphometry of the stridulation files for the recognition of cryptic species. Martins & Zefa (2011) , redescribed G ( G .) argentinus Saussure, 1874
morphologically and acoustically, this as derivative paper from Martins (2009) master’s thesis, in which he also studies two morphospecies, considered as new. Finally, the 40 Gryllus species
known for Latin America and the Caribbean are listed in Table 1 , with more valid and not dubious species in the island areas of the Caribbean and Galapagos than those found in the continental region, half of the species known to date lack acoustic data, thus suggesting that many Gryllus species
have yet to be studied at acoustic light.
